bioghist.p: Peter Olaus Okkelberg was born in Goodhue, Minnesota on November 12, 1880. He received his B.A. and M.A. degrees from the University of Minnesota, and his Ph.D. degree in zoology from the University of Michigan in 1918. After graduating from the University of Minnesota, Okkelberg came to the University of Michigan, first as an instructor in zoology, then after receiving his doctorate, as assistant professor (1918-1927), associate professor (1927-1929), as associate professor and executive secretary of the department (1929-1932), as professor and executive secretary of the department (1932-1933), as professor and secretary of the graduate school (1933-1936), as professor and assistant dean of the graduate school (1936-1947), and as professor and associate dean of the graduate school (1947-1951).

scopecontent.p: The Okkelberg collection is comprised of correspondence dating from 1910 to 1950, the approximate dates of his tenure at the University of Michigan. The correspondence is arranged chronologically and relates primarily to his career as a professor of zoology and to his work as an University of Michigan assistant and associate dean of the graduate school. Okkelberg corresponded with colleagues and administrators, within and outside the University of Michigan community. Correspondents include: Marion L. Burton, Oct. 1920, Robert M. Lovett, Sept. 1926, Jacob E. Reighard, July 1913, and Alexander G. Ruthven, June 1914 and April 1918.
